unnormalised: ## Automotive News: Understanding Revised Traffic Regulations
normalised: ## Automotive News: Understanding Revised Traffic Regulations

unnormalised: New Delhi – The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has recently updated several key traffic regulations aimed at improving road safety and streamlining enforcement across India. These changes, effective since October 26th, 2024, build upon the Motor Vehicles Act, incorporating learnings from analyses conducted by IIT Delhi's Transportation Research and Injury Prevention Programme.
normalised: New Delhi – The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has recently updated several key traffic regulations aimed at improving road safety and streamlining enforcement across India. These changes, effective since October twenty sixth, two thousand and twenty four, build upon the Motor Vehicles Act, incorporating learnings from analyses conducted by I I T Delhi's Transportation Research and Injury Prevention Programme.

unnormalised: Notably, fines for certain violations have been revised. For example, driving without a valid license now carries a penalty of Rs. 5000, while jumping a red light could cost you Rs. 2000. Emphasis is also placed on lane discipline, particularly on highways like the Mumbai-Pune Expressway, with strict enforcement planned using CCTV surveillance and on-the-spot fines for violations.
normalised: Notably, fines for certain violations have been revised. For example, driving without a valid license now carries a penalty of rupee five thousand, while jumping a red light could cost you rupee two thousand. Emphasis is also placed on lane discipline, particularly on highways like the Mumbai-Pune Expressway, with strict enforcement planned using C C T V surveillance and on-the-spot fines for violations.

unnormalised: The regulations also address issues like over-speeding, especially in residential areas, with speed limits reduced to 30 km/h in certain zones. A catchy public awareness campaign, reminiscent of dialogues from the Bollywood film "Drive", encourages citizens to "Drive safe, drive smart, life is precious!" The government hopes these updated regulations will reduce road accidents and promote responsible driving habits nationwide. Compliance is key to achieving safer roads for everyone.
